dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Kicking us off today, there's been a lot of buzz, uh, around this big Facebook advertising boycott, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Kicking us off today, there's been a lot of buzz, uh, around this big Facebook advertising boycott, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. I mean, it's huge. Over 500 companies have joined the #StopHateforProfit campaign now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. I mean, it's huge. Over five hundred companies have joined the Stop Hate for Profit campaign now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With over 500 companies having now joined the advertising boycott of Facebook called for by top civil rights groups...the #StopHateforProfits campaign, which has now grown to include more than 500 advertisers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Five hundred! That's a lot. And we even saw, like, Facebook's shares dip initially, right? Last Friday it was... what, eight percent?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Five hundred! That's a lot. And we even saw, like, Facebook's shares dip initially, right? Last Friday it was... what, eight percent?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebook shares initially plunged by 8% last Friday amid an increasing number of big brands

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, eight percent. It was a pretty big drop, especially with those major brands like Pfizer, Lego, and Dunkin' Donuts all jumping on board.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, eight percent. It was a pretty big drop, especially with those major brands like Pfizer, Lego, and Dunkin Donuts all jumping on board.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: most recently joined by Pfizer, Lego and Dunkin Donutsannouncing that they will stop working with the tech giant as part of the #StopHateforProfits campaign

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So you'd think, okay, this is a massive hit to Facebook. But, um, Wall Street seems to be, like, shrugging it off?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So you'd think, okay, this is a massive hit to Facebook. But, um, Wall Street seems to be, like, shrugging it off?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! That's the weird part. Most firms are still pretty bullish on the stock, actually, maintaining buy ratings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! That's the weird part. Most firms are still pretty bullish on the stock, actually, maintaining buy ratings.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Wall Street firms generally remain quite bullish on the stock, with the large majority reiterating buy ratings

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But how? I mean, 500 companies... that's gotta hurt the bottom line, surely?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But how? I mean, five hundred companies... that's gotta hurt the bottom line, surely?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, analysts are saying it's actually a pretty small hit. We're talking less than a five percent impact on overall revenue, even with all these companies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, analysts are saying it's actually a pretty small hit. We're talking less than a five percent impact on overall revenue, even with all these companies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: most Wall Street firms estimate that Facebook is still looking at less than a 5% hit to overall revenue.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Less than five percent? That just seemsâ€¦ low. Like, P&G, for example, they're the biggest advertiser in the world!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Less than five percent? That just seems... low. Like, P and G, for example, they're the biggest advertiser in the world!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Procter & Gamble, for example, is the largest advertiser in the world

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Right, and that's a good point. But even P&G, believe it or not, accounts for less than half a percent of Facebook's total revenue.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and that's a good point. But even P and G, believe it or not, accounts for less than half a percent of Facebook's total revenue.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Procter & Gamble, for example, is the largest advertiser in the world but is estimated to account for less than 0.50% of Facebooks revenues, he said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, uh, because Facebook has just *so* many advertisers, like millions of them, these big players leaving doesn't really move the needle that much?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, uh, because Facebook has just so many advertisers, like millions of them, these big players leaving doesn't really move the needle that much?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebook has a diverse revenue base, with millions of paying advertisers

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. I mean, Morgan Stanley even estimated that if Facebook lost its *top 100* advertisers, it'd only be about a billion a month.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. I mean, Morgan Stanley even estimated that if Facebook lost its top one hundred advertisers, it'd only be about a billion a month.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a scenario where the company loses business from its top 100 advertisers, that would only be around a $1 billion hit to revenue per month, Morgan Stanley analyst Brian Nowak estimates.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Only a billion. That's still a lot of money, but in Facebook terms... [pauses]... I guess it's not a catastrophic loss.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Only a billion. That's still a lot of money, but in Facebook terms... I guess it's not a catastrophic loss.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Not really, no. And apparently, advertisers were already scaling back spending, you know, because of the whole COVID-19 situation anyway.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not really, no. And apparently, advertisers were already scaling back spending, you know, because of the whole C O V I D-nineteen situation anyway.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Advertisers were already winding down spending amid the coronavirus pandemic, Kulkarni notes

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's almost like a combination of a diverse revenue base and, uh, just other market factors making this less impactful than it sounds?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's almost like a combination of a diverse revenue base and, uh, just other market factors making this less impactful than it sounds?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. Citi analysts even put it at about a dollar per share impact if the boycott only lasts a month. So, yeah, not as dire as it first appeared.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. Citi analysts even put it at about a dollar per share impact if the boycott only lasts a month. So, yeah, not as dire as it first appeared.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If the ad boycott only lasts one month, according to Citi analysts, the likely impact on Facebooks stock is just $1 per share

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. Fascinating. So, for all the headlines, Facebook's actually... pretty insulated, surprisingly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. Fascinating. So, for all the headlines, Facebook's actually... pretty insulated, surprisingly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it seems that way. For now, anyway.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it seems that way. For now, anyway.
